==10-XX and later== *'''10-14''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/1014/1014.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - ''Breast'' - Phase II. Repeat breast preserving surgery and 3D-CRT PBI for local recurrence
==00-XX to 09-XX== *'''09-37''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0937/0937.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/SCLC/RTOG_Lung|SCLC]] - Extensive stage. Phase III. PCI vs PCI + consolidative extra-cranial RT
*'''09-26''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0926/0926.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase II. T1. Selective bladder preservation **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''09-21''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0921/0921.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Endometrium/RTOG_Endometrium|Endometrium]] - Phase II. IMRT + concurrent cisplatin/bevacizumab + adjuvant carboplatin/paclitaxel
*'''09-20''' (ongoing) - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Head & Neck/Post-op|H&N]]'' - A phase III randomized trial of surgery followed by radiotherapy (IMRT) +/- cetuximab for intermediate risk HN SCCA
*'''09-15''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0915/0915.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase II randomized. SBRT inoperable central lesions 34/1 vs. 48/4
*'''08-15''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0815/0815.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Prostate/RTOG_Prostate|Prostate]] - Phase III randomized. Dose escalated RT ± 6 month ADT
*'''08-13''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0813/0813.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase I/II. SBRT inoperable peripheral lesions 50/5 -> 60/5
*'''07-24''' [http://rtog.org/members/protocols/0724/0724.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Cervix/RTOG Cervix|Cervix]]'' - High risk, early stage pts after Rad Hyst. Adjuvant Chemo/RT +/- adjuvant chemo.
*'''07-12''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0712/0712.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase II randomized. Selective bladder preservation RT + 5FU/cisplatin vs RT + gemcitabine **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''06-30''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0630/0630.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing - [[Radiation_Oncology/Sarcoma/RTOG_Sarcoma|Sarcoma]] - Phase II. Preop IGRT in the extremity
*'''06-23''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0623/0623.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - [[Radiation_Oncology/SCLC/RTOG_Lung|SCLC]] - Phase II. AHFX 61.2/34 Gy with concurrent cisplatin/etoposide and growth factor support **[[Radiation_Oncology/Lung/SCLC/Limited_Stage|chapter link]]
*'''06-18''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0618/0618.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase II. SBRT in operable patients. 60/3
*'''06-17''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0617/0617.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase III. Standard (60 Gy) vs. High Dose (74 Gy) concurrent with carbo/taxol +/- Cetuximab in Stage IIIA/IIIB
*'''05-38''' [http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials/CALGB-30610 Protocol Summary] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/SCLC/RTOG_Lung|SCLC]] - Phase III, 3 arms. 45/30 BID vs 70/35 QD vs AHFX 61.2/34. Concurrent cisplatin/etoposide **[[Radiation_Oncology/Lung/SCLC/Limited_Stage|chapter link]]
*'''05-29''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Anal_canal/RTOG_Anal|Anal]] - Phase II. Dose-painted IMRT **[[Radiation_Oncology/Anal_canal/RT_Technique|chapter link]]
*'''05-24''' (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - A Phase I/II Trial of a Combination of Paclitaxel and Trastuzumab With Daily Irradiation or Paclitaxel Alone With Daily Irradiation Following Transurethral Surgery for Non-Cystectomy Candidates With Muscle-Invasive Bladder Cancer. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''05-22''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0522/0522.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (2005-2009) - ''H&N'' - A phase III trial of concurrent accelerated radiation and cisplatin versus concurrent accelerated radiation, cisplatin, and cetuximab (C225) followed by surgery for residual disease for stage III and IV head and neck carcinomas. **2011: [http://abstract.asco.org/AbstView_102_79086.html ASCO Abstract 5500]
*'''05-21''' (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Prostate/RTOG_Prostate|Prostate]] - A Phase III Protocol of Androgen Suppression (AS) and 3DCRT/IMRT Vs AS and 3DCRT/IMRT Followed by Chemotherapy With Docetaxel and Prednisone for Localized, High-Risk Prostate Cancer
*'''05-15''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Comparative study of GTV definition +/- PET scan
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0438|04-38]]''' (ongoing) - ''Liver'' - Phase I. Dose escalation. 35 Gy in 3.5 Gy/fx -> 50 Gy in 5.0 Gy/fx in patients with metastatic liver cancer.
*'''04-36''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0436/0436.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) -- [[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/RTOG_Esophagus|Esophagus]] -- Phase III. Non-surgical approach. Paclitaxel + Cisplatin + RT +/- Cetuximab **[[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/Early_Stage|chapter link]]
*'''04-24''' (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/CNS/RTOG_Brain|Glioma]] - Phase II. High risk LGG (at least 3 risk factors: age >=40, tumor diameter >=6cm, tumor crossing midline, astrocytoma subtype, pre-op neurologic deficit). RT + Temozolomide. Comparison will be to historical EORTC patient population
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0421|04-21]]''' (Closed) - ''Head & Neck'' - Phase III. Locally recurrent, previously irradiated H&N: Concurrent Re-RT/Chemo vs. Chemo alone **Closed due to poor accrual
*'''04-18''' [http://rtog.org/members/protocols/0418/0418.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (Closed) - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Cervix/RTOG Cervix|Cervix]]''/Endometrial - Phase II. Post-op IMRT.
*'''04-17''' [http://rtog.org/members/protocols/0417/0417.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (Closed) - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Cervix/RTOG Cervix|Cervix]]'' - Phase II. Locally advanced. Definitive RT + cisplatin + bevacizumab.
*'''[[Radiation Oncology/RTOG Trials/0415|04-15]]''' (2006-2009) - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Prostate/RTOG Prostate|Prostate]]'' - Phase III. Low risk, T1-T2, PSA < 10, G 2-6. Randomized to 73.8 Gy in 41 fractions (1.8 Gy/fx) vs 70 Gy in 28 fractions (at 2.5 Gy/fx).
*'''04-13 / NSABP B-39''' (ongoing) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0413/0413.pdf Protocol] -- "A Randomized Phase III Study of Conventional Whole Breast Irradiation (WBI) Versus Partial Breast Irradiation (PBI) for Women with Stage 0, I, or II Breast Cancer"
*'''04-12 / SWOG S0332''' [http://rtog.org/members/protocols/0412/0412.pdf Protocol] - ''[[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]]'' - NSCLC Stage IIIA (N2) surgically resectable. Induction chemo vs chemo/RT followed by surgery then chemo. **Closed due to poor accrual
*'''04-11''' (2005-6) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Pancreas/RTOG_Pancreas|Pancreas]] - Phase II. RT + bevacizumab + capecitabine, with maintenance gemcitabine and bevacizumab **PMID 19636002 (2009)
*'''03-30''' [http://www.cancer.gov/search/ViewClinicalTrials.aspx?cdrid=365499&version=HealthProfessional&protocolsearchid=7628490 Protocol] - [[Radiation_Oncology/Sarcoma/RTOG_Sarcoma|Sarcoma]] - Phase II. Preop thalidomide and RT or doxorubicin/ifosfamide/dacarbazine and RT
*'''03-24''' [http://www.rtog.org/ClinicalTrials/ProtocolTable/StudyDetails.aspx?study=0324 Protocol] - ''NSCLC'' - Phase II. Chemo-RT + Cetuximab in Stage IIIA/IIIB **[[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/Locally_Advanced_Unresectable#Chemotherapy_combinations_with_RT | Chapter link]] **PMID 21555682 (2011)
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0321|03-21]]''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Prostate/RTOG_Prostate|Prostate]] - Intermediate localized PCA. 45 Gy EBRT (no IMRT) + 19 Gy (2 fractions) HDR boost **PMID 20207506 (2010): Acceptable toxicity
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0319|03-19]]''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0319/0319.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''Breast'' - Phase I/II. 3D-CRT confined to lumpectomy cavity for Stage I and II **[[Radiation_Oncology/Breast/Partial_breast_irradiation|chapter link]] **PMID 19910132 (2009): Initial efficacy and toxicity comparable
*'''03-15''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0315/0315.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''Supportive Care'' - Phase III. Octreotide for diarrhea prevention in anal and rectal cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Supportive_care/Diarrhea|chapter link]] **PMID 20339140 (2010): No benefit
*'''02-46''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/RTOG_Esophagus|Esophagus]] - Phase II. Paclitaxel Based Chemoradiation Regimen With Selective Surgical Salvage for Resectable Locoregionally Advanced Esophageal Cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/Early_Stage|chapter link]] **[http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0360301607013776 ASTRO Abstract]: Feasible
*'''02-41''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/SCLC/RTOG_Lung|SCLC]] - Phase I. Irinotectan + cisplatin + RT (45/30 BID or 70/35 QD in limited stage SCLC
*'''02-39''' (ongoing) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0239/0239.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - [[Radiation_Oncology/SCLC/RTOG_Lung|SCLC]]' - Phase II. Accelerated high dose RT (61.2 Gy in 5 weeks) with concurrent cisplatin/etoposide in limited small cell lung cancer
*'''02-36''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0236/0236.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase II. SBRT inoperable patients 60/3
*'''02-35''' [http://www.acrin.org/TabID/155/Default.aspx Protocol link] - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - PET for pre- and post- treatment assessment in locally advanced NSCLC
*'''02-34''' (ongoing) - ''H&N'' - Post-op. A phase II randomized trial of surgery followed by chemoradiotherapy plus C225 (cetuximab) for advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. **ASTRO Abstract 2007: RT + cisplatin or docetaxol + cetuximab is safe and feasible
*'''02-33''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - TURBT followed by induction chemo/RT (BID RT and randomized to Taxol + cisplatin vs 5-FU and cisplatin), evaluate tumor response, then consolidation chemo/RT (BID RT and randomized to same arm as above), then 4 cycles adjuvant chemo (Gemzar, Taxol, Cisplatin). Cystectomy for those who fail induction. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0232|02-32]]''' (ongoing) - ''Prostate'' - Intermediate localized PCA. EBRT + PB vs. PB alone
*'''02-29''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0229/0229.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase II. IIIA-B, resectable. Preop chemo/RT -> surgery -> additional chemo.
*'''02-25''' (2003-2005) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0225/0225.pdf Protocol] - ''H&N'' - Phase II. IMRT use in Nasopharynx **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Nasopharynx/Advanced_Stage|chapter link]] **PMID 19564532 (2009): IMRT feasible in multi-institutional setting
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0215|02-15]]''' (ongoing) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Prostate/RTOG_Prostate|Prostate]] - Treatment of ED. Sildenafil x 12 weeks crossover study.
*'''02-14''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0214/0214.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - PCI vs observation in locally advanced NSCLC
*'''02-13''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/0213/0213.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase I/II. Celebrex with RT in locally advanced NSCLC **Closed - poor accrual
*'''02-12 / Intergroup PCI99-01''' (1999-2005) [http://rtog.org/members/protocols/0212/0212.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - [[Radiation_Oncology/SCLC/RTOG_Lung|SCLC]] - PCI with Limited Disease SCLC - Intergroup study. PCI 25 Gy (at 2.5 Gy/fx) vs. 36 Gy (at 2/fx) vs. 36 Gy (at 1.5 BID). **[[Radiation_Oncology/Lung/SCLC/PCI|chapter link]] **PMID 19386548: No difference in brain mets, worse survival with higher dose
*'''02-11''' (2002-2004) [[Radiation_Oncology/CNS/High_grade_glioma/Adjuvant_therapy#Gefinitnib_.28Iressa.29|GBM]] - ''CNS'' - RT with concurrent/adjuvant gefitinib **PMID 23182702: Well tolerated but no benefit over historical controls
*'''01-32''' [http://www.cancer.gov/search/ViewClinicalTrials.aspx?cdrid=69111&version=HealthProfessional&protocolsearchid=7628499 Protocol] - [[Radiation_Oncology/Sarcoma/RTOG_Sarcoma|Sarcoma]] - Phase II. GIST. Neoadjuvant and adjuvant Gleevec
*'''01-29''' (2002-2005) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/h0129/h0129.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''H&N'' - Chemo/RT with conventional RT (70 Gy in 7 weeks) vs chemo/RT with concomitant boost (72 Gy in 6 weeks). Cisplatin (100 mg/m2) on days 1, 22, 43 (conventional) or 1 and 22 (C.B.). Enrolled selected Stage III-IV (T2N2-3M0, T3-4 Any N M0, no T1-2N1 or T1N2-3) **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **ASTRO 2007: Comparable acute toxicity
*'''01-28''' (closed March 2004) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/c0128/c0128.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Cervix/RTOG Cervix|Cervix]]'' - Phase I/II. Celecoxib + chemo/RT (cisplatin + 5-FU) for locally advanced cervical cancer, stage IIB-IVA or node-positive IB-IIA. **PMID 17482376 (2007), PMID 17084549 (2007), PMID 18299147 (2008), PMID 19509178 (2009)
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0126|01-26]]''' (ongoing) - ''Prostate'' - High dose 3D-CRT/IMRT randomized to 70.2 Gy vs. 79.2 Gy
*'''01-18''' (closed) - [[Radiation_Oncology/CNS/RTOG_Brain|Brain Mets]] - Phase III. WBRT 37.5/15 +/- Thalidomide **See [[Radiation_Oncology/Palliation/Brain_Metastases|chapter]] for more details **PMID 18164847, 2007 - No benefit
*'''[[Radiation Oncology/RTOG Trials/0117|01-17]]''' (closed) - [[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG_Lung|NSCLC]] - Phase I/II. Dose escalation, 3D-CRT + concurrent carboplatin/paclitaxel **[[Radiation_Oncology/NSCLC/Early_Stage_Inoperable|chapter link]] **PMID 20368547 (2010), PMID 20457350 (2010)
*'''01-16''' [http://rtog.org/members/protocols/c0116/c0116.pdf Protocol (PDF)] (2001-2007) - ''[[Radiation Oncology/Cervix/RTOG Cervix|Cervix]]'' - Phase I/II. Positive Para-Aortic LN (or high common iliac). Extended field RT +/- Amifostine. **PMID 17398031 (2007)
*'''01-14''' (closed)([http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/g0114/g0114.pdf Protocol]) - ''Gastric'' - Phase II. Randomized comparison of 2 chemo-RT regimens (Induction 5-FU/cisplatin/taxol + concurrent 5-FU/taxol + RT vs. induction cisplatin/taxol + concurrent cisplatin/taxol) **[[Radiation_Oncology/Stomach/Resectable|chapter link]] **ASTRO 2006 abstract: 5-FU arm too toxic **PMID 19273696 (2009)
*'''01-13''' (closed) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/RTOG_Esophagus|Esophagus]] - Phase III. Compares two induction + concurrent chemo/RT regimens) **[[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/Early_Stage|chapter link]] **PMID 18574157 (2008): Both arms too toxic
*'''00-24''' (2001-3) - ''H&N'' - post-operative chemo/RT. Early Taxol (within post-op day 7-14) then RT to 60 Gy with cisplatin/taxol weekly for the last 3 weeks **PMID 19720915 (2009)
*'''00-22''' (2001-2005) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/h0022/h0022.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''H&N'' - Phase I/II study of conformal and intensity modulated irradiation for oropharyngeal cancer. Stage T1-2, N0-1. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Oropharynx|chapter link]] **PMID 19540060 (2009): IMRT feasible
*'''00-20''' (Closed) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Pancreas/RTOG_Pancreas|Pancreas]] - Phase II, weekly gemcitabine + paclitaxel + XRT followed by farnesyl transferase inhibitor R115777 for locally advanced pancreatic cancer
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0019|00-19]]''' (closed) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Prostate/RTOG_Prostate|Prostate]] - Intermediate localized PCA. Phase II EBRT + PB
*'''00-17''' [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/L0017/L0017.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''[[Radiation Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG Lung|NSCLC]]'' - Phase I. GEM/paclitaxel vs. GEM/carboplatin and RT for Stage IIIA/B NSCLC **PMID 19096311 (2009)
*'''00-15''' [http://swog.org/intergroup/viewprotocol.asp?ProtocolNumber=S9900&AccessCode=32t6q69 SWOG S9900 Protocol] - ''[[Radiation Oncology/NSCLC/RTOG Lung|NSCLC]]'' - Phase III. Surgery vs Neoadjuvant paclitaxel/carboplatin for Stage IB, II, and selected IIIA patients **PMID 20231678
*'''00-12''' (2001-2003) - ''Rectum'' ([http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/r0012/r0012.pdf Protocol (PDF)]) - Randomized Phase II. Preoperative chemo/RT. **PMID 16446336, 2006 — "Randomized Phase II Study of Neoadjuvant Combined-Modality Chemoradiation for Distal Rectal Cancer: Radiation Therapy Oncology Group Trial 0012." Mohiuddin M et al. J Clin Oncol, Vol 24, No 4 (February 1), 2006: pp. 650-655.
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/0011|00-11]]''' (closed) - [[Radiation_Oncology/Prostate/RTOG_Prostate|Prostate]] - Unfavorable pT3 PCA s/p RP. AST x 2 years alone vs. EBRT + AST x 2 years vs. EBRT alone. Study closed due to non-accrual.
==90-XX to 99-XX== *'''99-15''' (Closed; pending) (Intergroup/SWOG 9927) - ''Breast'' - post-mastectomy RT for Stage II with 1-3 positive LN (T1-2N1)
*'''99-14''' (2000-2000) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/99-14/9914.pdf Protocol] - ''H&N'' - "A phase II trial of concomitant boost radiation and concurrent cisplatin for advanced head and neck carcinomas." **PMID 15860857 (2005): Concomitant boost + concurrent cisplatin is feasible **PMID 18640496 (2008): long term results
*'''99-13''' (2000-2) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/99-13/9913.pdf Protocol] - ''H&N'', ''Skin Toxicity'' - "A phase III comparison of Biafine to declared institutional preference for radiation induced skin toxicity in patients undergoing radiation therapy fro advanced squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck." **PMID 16648511 (2006)
*'''99-11''' (2000-2003) [http://www.rtog.org/members/protocols/99-11/99-11.pdf Protocol (PDF)] - ''H&N'' - "Phase II Study of Paciltaxel and Cisplatin in Combination with split course concomitant hyperfractionated re-irradiation in patients with recurrent squamous cell cancer of the head and neck." **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General#Reirradiation|Chapter]]. PMID 17947728: High incidence of Grade 5 toxicity, but better OS than chemo alone
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/9910|99-10]]''' (1999-2004) - ''Prostate'' - Intermediate risk PCA. AST/2 followed by EBRT/AST vs. AST/7 followed by EBRT/AST.

*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/9714|97-14]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate, Breast, Palliation'' - Mets to bone. 3 Gy x 10 vs. 8Gy x 1 **Conclusion [http://www.rtog.org/abstracts/astrolist.html#Hartsell ASTRO 2003 Abstract] : "Palliative external beam radiation therapy is very effective in providing pain relief, with complete or partial improvement in pain seen in 66% of patients. *'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/9408|94-08]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - Intermediate risk localized PCA. AST/2 followed by EBRT vs. EBRT alone.
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/9406|94-06]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - Phase I, 3D-CRT dose escalation, 68.4 - 79.2Gy. **Conclusion level V (78 Gy in 2 Gy/fx) [http://www.rtog.org/abstracts/astrolist.html#Michalski ASTRO Abstract] : "The rate of grade 3+ toxicity from 3DCRT with 78 Gy in 2.0 Gy fractions remains better than expected compared to historical controls. These differences may be dose and/or volume related." **Conclusion level IV (74 Gy in 2 Gy/fx) PMID 14967428 : "Tolerance to three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy with 74 Gy in 2-Gy fractions remains better than expected compared with historical controls. The magnitude of any effect from fraction size requires additional follow-up."
*'''94-05''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/RTOG_Esophagus|Esophagus]] - high (64.8 Gy) versus standard (50.4 Gy) dose **[[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/Early_Stage|Chapter link]] **No difference in survival or loco-regional control
*'''94-04''' - ''Lung'' - RT 60/30 +/- interferon beta **PMID 11955727 - <u>Conclusion</u>: "This multicenter, controlled Phase III trial failed to confirm the efficacy of Betaseron in patients receiving definitive radiotherapy for locally advanced, nonmetastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. Induction CT/RT, followed by intra-arterial cisplatin and I-131 Antiferritin **Conclusion PMID 9612600 "Patients with unresectable alpha-fetoprotein-positive hepatocellular carcinoma experienced improved survival and decreased toxicity when managed with post-induction cycles of intra-arterial cisplatin as compared with intravenous doxorubicin and 5-FU. Intravenous 131I-polyclonal antiferritin did not improve survival when added to either post-induction regimen but dramatically increased hematologic toxicities."
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8822|88-22]]''' (closed) - ''Palliation'' - Prostate or Breast bone mets. Dose-escalated fractionated hemibody irradiation **PMID 8823257 : "The maximum tolerated dose of fractionated (2.50 Gy) HBI was found to be 17.5 Gy. The major dose limiting toxicity was hematological (thromboleukopenia). There was not a significant dose response effect on occult disease (appearance of new disease) or in the requirement for additional treatment, although certain trends were noted for the higher doses. When only patients completing assigned HBI from RTOG 82-06 and 88-22 were compared, there was no difference in the time to new disease or additional treatment in the treated field. Based on the investigative parameters of this study, single high-dose HBI was as effective as fractionated HBI."

*'''88-14''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase II. Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy with MCV (MTX/CDDP/VBL) with Intraoperative Electron Beam Radiotherapy and Pre- and Postoperative External Beam Radiotherapy in Patients with Invasive Bladder Carcinoma **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''88-09''' - ''H&N'' - Phase I/II, comparing two accelerated fractionation: Split course 1.6 Gy BID to 67.2 Gy, 2 week break after 38.4 Gy vs. 1.8 Gy + 1.5 Gy concomitant boost for last 11 fractions to 70.5 Gy **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **PMID 7790243: both arms can be used successfully
*'''88-08''' / ECOG 4588 - ''NSCLC'' - Unresectable Stage II-IIIB. std RT vs induction chemo/RT vs hyperfractionated RT. **PMID 7707407 (1995), PMID 10669675 (2000)
*'''88-06''' - ''CNS lymphoma'' - Phase I/II. HIV-negative CNS lymphoma treated with CHOD x 2 -> WBRT to 41.4 Gy boosted to 59.4 Gy. ** PMID 8636771 (1996)
*'''88-04''' - ''NSCLC'' - Phase II. Unresectable. Induction/concurrent vinblastine + cisplatin. **PMID 1313202 (1992), SCLV mets - PMID 10386642
*'''88-02''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Operable T2-T4a . Bladder preservation. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]] **PMID 8558186 (1996)
*'''87-05''' - ''Hyperthermia'' - Phase I/II. Radiotherapy and Hyperthermia in Patients with Selected Measurable Superficial Tumors **PMID 8256760
*'''87-04''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Anal_canal/RTOG_Anal|Anal]] - Phase III. RT + 5-FU + Mitomycin vs RT + 5-FU **[[Radiation_Oncology/Anal_canal/Overview|chapter link]] **PMID 8823332 (1996): Use of Mitomycin necessary
*'''87-03''' - ''Hyperthermia'' - Phase I/II. Combined Modality Therapy with DDP and Regional Hyperthermia in Patients with Malignancies of the Pelvis and Lower Abdomen
*'''86-12''' - ''CNS'' - IUdR **PMID 8407393 (1993), 8985039 (1996)
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8610|86-10]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - Concurrent and adjuvant Zoladex + Flutamide with XRT. Bulky primary disease (>25 cc) **PMID 18172188 (2008) **Conclusion PMID 11483335 : "In patients with Gleason score 2--6 carcinoma of the prostate, a short course of androgen ablation administered before and during radiotherapy has been associated with a highly significant improvement in local control, reduction in disease progression, and overall survival."
*'''86-09''' - ''Neutron Therapy'' [http://www.cancer.gov/search/ViewClinicalTrials.aspx?cdrid=74211&version=HealthProfessional&protocolsearchid=6022220 cancer.gov link] - Phase III
*'''86-08''' - Rectum, Cervix, [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase I/II. WR-2721 Administered Before Protracted Fractionated Radiotherapy in Patients with Cancer of the Rectum, Cervix, or Bladder
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8531|85-31]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - N+ or cT3/pT3, Zoladex at time of radiation vs radiation alone. Excluded bulky disease (see 86-10) unless there was +LN outside of pelvis. **Conclusion PMID 15817329 : "In a population of patients with unfavorable prognosis carcinoma of the prostate, androgen suppression applied as an adjuvant after definitive RT was associated not only with a reduction in disease progression but in a statistically significant improvement in absolute survival. The improvement in survival appeared preferentially in patients with a Gleason score of 7-10."
*'''85-30''' - ''H&N'' - Standard surgery +/- cricopharyngeal myotomy **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Post-op|chapter link]] **PMID 10488976: No benefit
*'''85-28''' - ''CNS'' - solitary brain met, Phase I/II, dose escalation with hyperfractionated boost. **PMID 8435812 — "Improved survival duration in patients with unresected solitary brain metastasis using accelerated hyperfractionated radiation therapy at total doses of 54.4 gray and greater. Results of Radiation Therapy Oncology Group 85-28." Epstein BE et al. Cancer. 1993 Feb 15;71(4):1362-7. **PMID 8330997 **NOTE:Countered by 91-04
*'''85-27''' - ''H&N'' - etanidazole + XRT **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General#Radiosensitizers_and_hypoxic_cell_sensitizers|chapter link]] **PMID 7790241: no difference
*'''85-12''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - T2-4. Bladder preservation. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]] **PMID 8478228 (1993)
*'''85-06''' - ''Bile Duct'' - Phase I/II. Unresected, resected but residual, or locally recurrent biliary duct cancer. Intra-op RT (14-22 Gy) followed by EBRT (45-50 Gy). 2/8 pts alive at publication w/ median follow-up 10.5 months **PMID 1514529 -- ''Intraoperative radiation therapy of extrahepatic biliary carcinoma: a report of RTOG-8506.'' (Wolkov HB, Am J Clin Oncol. 1992 Aug;15(4):323-7.)
*'''85-03''' (INT 0034) - ''H&N'' - Post-op RT vs. post-op cisplatin/5-FU then RT **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Post-op|chapter link]] **PMID 1618662: No benefit
*'''85-02''' (1985-89) - ''Gyn / Palliation'' - Phase I/II? Palliation for advanced pelvic malignancies. 3.7 Gy BID to 44.4 Gy with break after 4th and 8th fractions. Break duration randomized 2 vs 4 wks. **[[Radiation Oncology/Palliation/Pelvic|chapter link]] **PMID 8083097 (1994), PMID 7679668 (1993), PMID 2476426 (1989)
*'''85-01''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Esophagus/RTOG_Esophagus|Esophagus]] - XRT alone vs XRT/Chemo - increased OS for T1-3 N0-1 M0 squamous cell and adenocarcinomas **Update: [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=pubmed&dopt=Abstract&list_uids=10235156 Abstract] [http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/full/281/17/1623 Full text] — "Chemoradiotherapy of locally advanced esophageal cancer: long-term follow-up of a prospective randomized trial (RTOG 85-01). Radiation Therapy Oncology Group." Cooper et al. JAMA. 1999 May 5;281(17):1623-7. **First report: [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=pubmed&dopt=Abstract&list_uids=1584260 Abstract] — "Combined chemotherapy and radiotherapy compared with radiotherapy alone in patients with cancer of the esophagus." Herskovic et al. N Engl J Med. 1992 Jun 11;326(24):1593-8. **Race: [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=pubmed&dopt=Abstract&list_uids=10421537 Abstract: Does Race Influence Survival?] — "Does race influence survival for esophageal cancer patients treated on the radiation and chemotherapy arm of RTOG #85-01?" Streeter et al. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys. 1999 Jul 15;44(5):1047-52.
*'''84-19''' - [http://www.cancer.gov/search/ViewClinicalTrials.aspx?cdrid=73295&version=HealthProfessional&protocolsearchid=7628511 Protocol] ''Recurrent or persistent tumors'' -- Phase III Randomized Study of Interstitial Thermoradiotherapy vs Interstitial Radiotherapy Alone for Metastatic, Recurrent, or Persistent Tumors **PMID 8600093 (1996): No benefit as delivered
*'''84-12 / GOG 71''' (1984-91) - ''Cervix'' - TREATMENT OF PATIENTS WITH SUB-OPTIMAL (BULKY) STAGE 1B CARCINOMA OF THE CERVIX. A RANDOMIZED OF RADIATION THERAPY VS RADIATION PLUS ADJUVANT EXTRAFACIAL HYSTRECTOMY **PMID 12798694, 2003 - Keys
*'''84-11''' - ''H&N, Breast,'' [[Radiation_Oncology/Sarcoma/RTOG_Sarcoma|Sarcoma]] - Phase III Randomized Comparison of Radiotherapy plus Hyperthermia vs Radiotherapy Alone in the Treatment of Patients with Head and Neck Carcinoma, Breast Cancer, or Soft Tissue Sarcoma Amenable to Potentially Curable Radiotherapy
*'''84-07''' (1984-89) - ''Lung NSCLC'' - Phase I/II, concomitant boost: 45 Gy/1.8 (daily) + 18 Gy/10 fx (2-3x/week) = 63 Gy; escalate to 50.4 + 19.8 Gy = 70.2 Gy / 5.5 wks or 45 + 25.2 = 70.2 Gy / 5 wks. **PMID 7836079, 1993
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8405|84-05]]''' (closed) - ''Liver'' - Phase I/II dose escalation, GI liver mets, whole liver RT 1.5 Gy BID escalated to 27, 30, 33, 36 Gy (not reached). **Conclusion: PMID 8365932 "The study design could not credibly establish a safe dose for hepatic irradiation, however, it did succeed in determining that 33 Gy in fractions of 1.5 Gy is unsafe, carrying a substantial risk of delayed radiation injury. The absence of apparent late liver injury at the 27 Gy and 30 Gy dose levels suggests that a prior clinical trial of adjuvant hepatic irradiation in patients with resected colon cancer may have employed an insufficient radiation dose (21 Gy) to fully test the question."
*'''RTOG 84-03''' - ''Lung NSCLC / PCI'' - RT alone vs RT + PCI for NSCLC (non-metastatic). **PMID 1651304, 1991
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8319|83-19]]''' (closed) - ''Liver'' - Phase III. HCC. CT/RT Induction followed 1 month later by CT +/- 131-I-Antiferritin **Conclusion PMID 9612600: "Intravenous 131-I-polyclonal antiferritin did not improve survival when added to either post-induction regimen but dramatically increased hematologic toxicities."
*'''83-15''' (1983-87) - ''CNS Lymphoma'' - Phase II. RT alone, 40 Gy WBRT + 20 Gy boost. **PMID 1572835, 1992
*'''83-14''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Anal_canal/RTOG_Anal|Anal]] - Phase II. RT + 5-FU + Mitomycin **[[Radiation_Oncology/Anal_canal/Overview|chapter link]] **PMID 2724350 (1989): Effective
*'''83-13''' (1983-1987) - ''H&N'' - hyperfractionation dose escalation: 1.2 Gy BID to 67.2 Gy, 72.0 Gy, 76.8 Gy, 81.6 Gy **PMID 2180866 (Preliminary): Higher LC with 72.0 and 76.8 Gy hyperfractionated, led to RTOG 90-03 **PMID 7790242 (Long-term): No increase in late toxicity
*'''83-12''' - ''Lung NSCLC'' - Phase I/II, T3-T4 NSCLC. Concomitant boost at 1.8 Gy/fx to 50.4 Gy (elective nodal). Primary tumor to 2.68 Gy/day to total of 75 Gy in 28 fx. **PMID 7860394 (1995)
*'''83-11''' - ''Lung NSCLC'' - Phase I/II dose escalation, randomized to 1.2 Gy BID to 60.0, 64.8, 69.6 Gy, 74.4 Gy or 79.2 Gy. **PMID 2167952 (1990)
*'''83-03''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase I/II. Dose escalation 60.0 Gy, 64.8 Gy, or 69.6 Gy. Evaluation of Twice-Daily Fractional Radiotherapy for Locally Advanced Stage B/C/D Transitional Cell and Unresectable Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Bladder **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]] **PMID 3058657 (1988): Good tolerance to hyperfractionation
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8307|83-07]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - XRT + DES vs XRT + Megace - similar results but different toxicities **Conclusion PMID 7721614 : "The results of the study indicate comparable efficacy (using tumor clearance as an end point) of DES and Megestrol. Although DES appears more effective in suppressing testosterone, it is also associated with a higher incidence of drug-related toxicity."
*'''83-05''' - ''Melanoma'' - dose per fraction. 4 x 8.0 Gy (32 Gy) once weekly vs 20 x 2.5 Gy (50 Gy) 5 days/week. **PMID 1995527 — "Fraction size in external beam radiation therapy in the treatment of melanoma." Sause WT et al. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys. 1991 Mar;20(3):429-32.
*'''[[Radiation Oncology/RTOG Trials/8302|83-02]]''' (1983-89) - ''CNS'' - Phase I/II. High grade gliomas. Dose-escalation of hyperfractionated or accelerated HF RT with BCNU. **PMID 8608540 (1996), PMID 8380567 (1993), PMID 1451073 (1992)
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8301|83-01]]''' (closed) - ''Liver'' - Phase I/II. HCC. Induction CT+RT, followed 1 month later by 131-I-antiferritin + CT **Conclusion PMID 2415692: "These studies have demonstrated the toxicity and therapeutic activity of 131I antiferritin and the emerging role of radiolabelled antibody in cancer therapy."
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8206|82-06]]''' (closed) - ''Palliation'' - Bone mets. 30 Gy EBRT +/- 8 Gy hemibody irradiation **Conclusion PMID 1374061 : "This clinical trial demonstrates that HBI has the potential to be used to treat systemic and occult metastases, particularly if both halves of the body can be treated."
*'''81-17''' - ''H&N'' - Piloted RT + chemo. Standard RT with concomitant cisplatin (100 mg/m2) q3weeks x 3 courses. Included oropharynx, nasopharynx, oral cavity. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **PMID 3802013 and PMID 2224782: Concurrent cisplatin + RT safe and effective; led to RTOG 91-11
*'''81-16''' - ''H&N'' - Phase I/II. Induction cisplatin/5-FU + surgery + RT (42 patients) or surgery + sequential cisplatin/5-FU + RT (29 patients) **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Post-op|chapter link]] **PMID 1998567: No difference between induction or sequential chemo
*'''81-10''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase III Photon vs Mixed Beam Preoperative Radiotherapy for Stage B/C/D Carcinoma of the Bladder **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''81-08''' - ''Lung NSCLC'' - feasibility study of hyperfractionated RT **PMID 1650526 (1991)
*'''81-06''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase III Randomized Comparison of Sandwich vs Standard Preoperative Adjuvant Radiotherapy in Stage B/C Bladder Cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''81-05''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase I/II Misonidazole and Radiotherapy for Inoperable Bladder Cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''80-05''' (1980-84) - ''Cervix'' - RT +/- misonidazole **[[Radiation_Oncology/Cervix/Locally_Advanced#RT_vs._Chemo-RT|link to text]]. Negative trial **PMID 3104249 (prelim, 1987), PMID 10348279 (final results, 1999)
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/8003|80-03]]''' (closed) - ''Liver'' - Phase III. Liver mets. RT +/- radiosensitization with misonidazole **PMID 3597149: No benefit
==70-XX to 79-XX== *'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/7928|79-28]]''' (closed) - ''Liver'' - Phase I/II. 131-I-Antiferrin, Liver RT and ADR/5-FU **Conclusion: PMID 6275989 - "Present results suggest that further clinical studies with isotopic immunoglobulin are indicated."
*'''79-20''' (1979-86) - ''Cervix'' - Pelvic only vs Pelvic + Paraaortic RT. **PMID 2211198 (1990), PMID 7616634 (1995)
*'''79-16''' (1979-83) - ''CNS'' - Brain mets. Randomized to 30/10 vs 30 Gy/6 fx/3 wks, and +/- misonidazole **PMID 1993631
*'''79-15''' - ''H&N'' - Misonidazole **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General#Hypoxia|chapter link]] **Hemoglobin concentration - PMID 2689395 (1989)
*'''79-13''' - ''H&N'' - Hyperfractionated 1.2 Gy BID vs. standard fractionation **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **PMID 3542916: No difference, worse acute toxicity
*'''79-05''' (1979-82) - ''Gyn/Palliative'' - 10 Gy x 3 courses, 4-wk apart **[[Radiation Oncology/Palliation/Pelvic|chapter link]] **PMID 2442127 (1987)
*'''79-04''' - ''H&N'' - Hypofractionated RT +/- Misonidazole **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General#Hypoxia|chapter link]] **PMID 2646255: No difference
*'''78-26''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Photon Radiotherapy vs Pion Radiotherapy for Transitional Cell Carcinoma of the Urinary Bladder **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''78-21''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase I/II Radiosensitization with Misonidazole plus Radiotherapy for Bladder Cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]] **PMID 7180834
*'''78-17''' - Hypoxia - Phase II Study of Misonidazole plus Intraoperative Radiotherapy for Nonresectable Carcinomas
*'''78-16''' - Hyperthermia - Phase I-II Hyperthermia (43.5 Degrees Centigrade) Before and After Radiation Treatment for Human Tumors
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/7810|78-10]]''' (closed) - ''Palliation'' - Bone mets. Hemibody dose escalation **Conclusion: PMID 2423225 - "HBI achieves pain relief sooner and with less evidence of pain recurrence in the irradiated area than conventionally treated patients. The most effective and safest of the HBI doses tested were 600 rad for the upper HBI and 800 rad for the lower or mid-HBI."
*'''78-04''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Adjuvant Radiotherapy before and after Surgery for Bladder Cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]] **PMID 3967204
*'''78-03''' - ''H&N'' - Phase I/II. Induction cisplatin + bleomycin prior to RT **PMID 6159067: Low morbidity but not very effective
*'''78-02''' - ''H&N'' - Phase II. Misonidazole pilot trial **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General#Hypoxia|chapter link]] **PMID 7333912: 67% CR rate in Stage III-IV
*'''77-08''' - ''H&N'' - PI/II. Advanced patients. Induction VCR+Bleo+MTX **PMID 6180625: satisfactory result
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/7706|77-06]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - Prostate field vs. Whole pelvis + prostate boost. Stage A2-B, N0. **Conclusion: PMID 3058656 - "The results of the study revealed no statistically significant benefit of elective pelvic irradiation.
*'''77-05''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Radiotherapy with Neutrons Alone or with Photons with or without Surgery for Urinary Bladder Cancer **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]] **PMID 6375854
*'''77-03''' - ''H&N'' - Phase I/II. Hyperfractionation pilot: 1.25 Gy BID and 1.5 Gy BID **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **1.2 Gy BID tolerable; 1.5 Gy BID too toxic. Led to RTOG 79-13
*'''76-19''' - ''H&N'' - Registry study **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **PMID 2674073: Risk of second primary cancers 15% at 5 years
*'''76-15''' - ''H&N'' - Phase I-II. Neoadjuvant and concurrent chemo-RT (VBM=VCR,Bleo,MTX) **Too toxic <!--N.B. This is not PMID 6159067 which is RTOG 78-03-->
*'''76-13''' - ''H&N'' - Phase I-II. Combined multidrug chemo/RT (Cytoxan,VCR,Bleo) + adjuvant chemo **PMID 85493: Too toxic
*'''76-12''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Preoperative or Postoperative Radiotherapy or Radiotherapy Alone for Clinical Stage B1 or B2 or C Bladder Carcinoma **[[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/Muscle_Invasive|chapter link]]
*'''76-08''' - ''Cervix'' - Phase III. Photons vs. photons + neutrons **No difference
*'''76-06''' (1976-79) - ''CNS'' - Brain mets, favorable patient population (controlled primary, no extracranial mets). Rand to 30/10 vs 50/20 **PMID 6171553
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/7605|76-05]]''' (closed) - ''Liver'' - Phase I. Treatemnt of liver mets with RT
*'''[[Radiation_Oncology/RTOG_Trials/7506|75-06]]''' (closed) - ''Prostate'' - Pelvis XRT +/- periaortic nodes **PMID 3494005
*'''74-02''' - ''Bone metastases'' - Solitary 40.5/15 vs. 20/5; Multiple 30/10 vs. 15/5 vs. 20/5 vs. 25/5 **PMID 6178497 (1982)
*'''74-01 / ECOG 1374''' - ''CNS'' - High grade glioma. 1) 60 Gy whole brain vs 2)60 Gy + 10 Gy boost vs 3)60 Gy + BCNU vs 4)60 Gy + CCNU + DTIC **PMID 3281031 (1988)
*'''73-61''' (1973-76) - ''CNS'' - Brain mets. Various doses: 20/5, 30/10, 40/15. Ultra-rapid: 6 Gy x 2. (RTOG 69-01 and 73-61 are grouped together.) **PMID 6154024, PMID 6174490, PMID 6169424
*'''73-03''' (1973-79) - ''H&N'' - Pre-op 50 Gy vs Post-op 60 Gy RT. **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Post-op|chapter link]] **PMID 3449477: Post-op better
*'''73-02''' - ''Lung NSCLC'' - T4 or N3 (IIIB). Palliation. Randomized to 30 Gy, 40 Gy continuous, or 40 Gy split. **PMID 2579938 (1985)
*'''73-01''' - ''Lung NSCLC'' - Stage III. Randomized to 40 Gy split course or 40 Gy, 50 Gy, or 60 Gy continuous. **PMID 6998937 (1980 - patterns of tumor recurrence)
*'''71-05''' - ''Cervix'' - Phase III. Stage IIB-IVA. Randomized to RT 51/30 vs. split course 25/10 + 25/10. Both followed by BT boost 30 Gy LDR **[[Radiation_Oncology/Cervix/Locally_Advanced|chapter link]] **PMID 6406397: No difference
*'''71-04''' - [[Radiation_Oncology/Bladder/RTOG_Bladder|Bladder]] - Phase III. Stage C or D1. Randomized to RT 60/30 vs. split course 27.5/10 + 27.5/10 **PMID 4050737: No difference
*'''71-03''' - ''H&N'' - Phase III. Nasopharynx. Randomized to RT 66/33 vs. split course 30/10 + 30/10 **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Nasopharynx/Early_Stage|chapter link]] **PMID 6993442: No difference
*'''71-02''' - ''H&N'' - Phase III. Base of tongue. Randomized to RT 66/33 vs. split course 30/10 + 30/10 **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Oropharynx|chapter link]] **PMID 6343309: No difference
*'''71-01''' - ''H&N'' - Phase III. Tonsillar fossa. Randomized to RT 66/33 vs. split course 30/10 + 30/10 **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/Oropharynx|chapter link]] **PMID 8213620: No difference
*'''70-02''' - ''H&N'' - Phase III. RT +/- Carbogen **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **PMID 120869: No difference
*'''70-01''' - ''Cervix'' - Phase III. RT vs. Hypofractionated RT + Hyperbaric Oxygen **[[Radiation_Oncology/Cervix/Locally_Advanced|chapter link]] **PMID 7028700: No difference
==Pre 70-XX== *'''69-01''' (1971-73) - ''CNS'' - Brain mets. Various doses: 30/10, 30/15, 40/15, 40/20. Ultra-rapid: 10 Gy x 1. (RTOG 69-01 and 73-61 are grouped together.) **PMID 6154024, PMID 6174490, PMID 6169424
*'''68-01''' (1968-1972) - ''H&N'' - Phase III. Stage III-IV OC, OP, SGL, HP. Randomized to RT alone vs. induction MTX followed by RT **[[Radiation_Oncology/Head_%26_Neck/General|chapter link]] **PMID 7410127: No benefit

'''Chemical Series of the Periodic Table'''
[[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Group 1|Alkali metals]] [[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Group 2|Alkaline earths]] [[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Inner Transition Metals#Lanthanoids|Lanthaniods]] [[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Inner Transition Metals#Actinoids|Actinoids]] [[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Transition Metals|Transition metals]]
[[w:Poor metal|Poor metal]]s [[w:Metalloid|Metalloid]]s [[w:Nonmetal|Nonmetal]]s [[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Group 17|Halogens]] [[General Chemistry/Chemistries of Various Elements/Group 18|Noble gases]]
'''How to remember the first 20 elements easily '''
'''This method was made by Sanjith Sagar, a student of Glendale Academy International, Hyderabad, India. He's currently in Grade 10. He considered the first 20 elements and made various combinations to form words. All you have to do is remember the word sequence and you'll automatically get the table.'''

First thing he did was make various pairs of elements.
(Below is the short form of the elements. Remember it this way)
'''H'''
'''He'''
'''Li'''
'''Be'''
'''B|'''
'''C|'''
'''N|'''
'''O|'''
'''F|'''
'''Ne~'''
'''Na~'''
'''Mg]'''
'''Al]'''
'''Si^'''
'''P^'''
'''S^'''
'''Cl-'''
'''Ar-'''
'''K-'''
'''Ca'''
('''The |,^,~,etc. Are the different groups in which the elements are classfied. Meaning B,C,N,O,F are one group.''')


'''Consider the first group. H,He,Li,Be. Remember as it is. It's a nice ring to it which helps. One advise is remember it as the Full forms. Hydrogen, Helium, Lithium and Beryllium. End with -ium'''
'''Next group is B,C,N,O,F. All these are single letters. REMEMBER THEM LIKE A RUSSIAN NAME, BCNOF or remember it using the short forms because in this group all are alphabets not a combination like Be or Cl.'''
'''Next group is Ne,Na. Okay try reading it together. Sounds like Nina(NeNa) right?. So that's how you remember it'''
'''Next group is Mg,Al. Try reading this as well. Sounds like Migal(MgAl) right? Remember it this way'''
'''Next group is Si,P,S. We can make a proper word out of this. Sips(Si,P,S).'''
'''Next group is Cl,Ar,K. Make a word out of this. Clark(Cl,Ar,K).'''
'''And finally. Remember Ca as it is'''



'''The first 20 elements is very much required to do well in chemistry.''' '''The order mentioned above is the ascending order of atomic number of elements'''




'''So it is:'''
'''The ring, BCNOF, Nina(NeNa), Migal(Mg,Al), Sips(Si,P,S), Clark(Cl,Ar,K) and Ca'''
==External Links== [http://touchspin.touchspin.com/DisplayTable.php Touchspin's Interactive Periodic Table] {{BookCat}} [[it:Chimica generale/Tavola periodica]] Elements 103-118 don't have the same atomic [weight] represented everywhere.
Elements with [atomic weights in brackets] are rounded from their actual atomic weights.
Metals, metalloids, and nonmetals have no one definition.

Is this book over PowerPC assembly or 68K assembly. The introduction would have you think that the 68K and the PPC are compatable. So, if this book wants to hold true to its title, then all the material should be removed. Otherwise the title of the book should be changed to 68K Assembly.
: Fixed. The title is now [[68000 Assembly]], the [[PowerPC Assembly]] is a completely separate book, and the confusion between them in the text has now been fixed to point out that they are, in fact, completely different assembly languages. --[[User:DavidCary|DavidCary]] ([[User talk:DavidCary|talk]]) 14:59, 9 September 2009 (UTC)

== Pruning ==
As this is ostensibly a bartender's guide, wouldn't it make sense to remove recipes for things like Eggnog that would never be produced by a bartender? Also, it seems reasonable to separate cocktails and shooters onto separate pages. Thoughts?
For that matter, is anyone actively reading this at all?
: I am. Though there is not much going on here it seems. Similar to the [[w:Wikipedia:WikiProject Cocktails|WikiProject Cocktails]] project. I would encourage anyone reading this to join the Project over there so we can get some cross-wiki discussion going on. I think there are several ways we can help each other out.
: As to the ''eggnog'' question, the same type of question has come up over there. What I am proposing at Wikipedia is to make "mixed drinks", not cocktails, be the top-level of the hirearchy. True cocktails would be the largest section thereunder, but there would also be places for things like eggnog, spritzers, beer mixes, and other things that aren't technically cocktails. I'm not sure how things are organized here, but you might consider something similar to that if it makes sense in your wikiverse. :-) --[[User:Willscrlt|Willscrlt]] 13:04, 9 December 2006 (UTC)
== Fleshing Out Cocktail List == Over the next little while, I'm going to flesh out the cocktails list by creating all the non-existant pages linked to from this main page, and filling in recipes as described by Google, the almighty. These should be fairly correct, but I'm sure people will want to then make alterations for accuracy/variations. Hope this helps. [[User:Lor|Lor]] 21:37, 5 September 2005 (UTC) == Indik == Wikipedia is discussing deleting a recipe for a cocktail purportedly named "Indik". See [[w:Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Indik]]. If any editors wish to have the recipe transwikied to here, please say so in that discussion. [[User:Uncle G|Uncle G]] 00:32, 19 September 2005 (UTC)
== Field research? ==
{{Bartending:region|This is the (region)}} Barmeister and drinkmixer and iDrink and friends are all giving different results. I'm going to do some field research; I've added a Bartending:region|(region) template in case anyone does some field research and polls at least say 5 bartenders from your area, preferably in different establishments. It's shown to the right. It may be wise to regionalize the bartending wikibook, or find another way to denote that things come from various regions.
I'm especially interested in non-alcoholic cocktails, being myself one who dislikes alcohol's flavor and effects. I don't get off on being slightly out of it, or plastered to the wall, or vomiting in someone's face; I like my brain operating at peak efficiency at all times. This is my only strong interest in this wikibook; plus it will help eat some of my free time on weekends, social engineering my way into bars.
== I'm a newcomer - is this still active? ==
I'm slightly newish to Wikipedia and Wikibooks and I'm just wondering if these projects are still active? [[User:Italydiplo|Italydiplo]] ([[User talk:Italydiplo|talk]]) 06:00, 8 July 2008 (UTC)

I edited and moved around a bunch of stuff, hopefully clarifying the writing in the process. The original author seemed to confuse statistics (e.g., "how many people in the US have green eyes") with probability (e.g., "if I grab thirty random people off of the street what is the probability that 3 of them will have green eyes"). I also removed some of the "informal" language and rephrased it to be a little more technical. --[[User:Llywelyn|Llywelyn]] 09:43, 11 Oct 2004 (UTC)

{{Statistics/Navigation}} [[Image:Dices1-6.png|250px|right|thumb|When throwing two dice, what is the probability that their sum equals seven?]] Probability is connected with some unpredictability. We know what outcomes may occur, but not exactly which one. The set of possible outcomes plays a basic role. We call it the ''sample space'' and indicate it by S. Elements of S are called ''outcomes''. In rolling a dice the sample space is S = {1,2,3,4,5,6}. Not only do we speak of the outcomes, but also about ''events'', sets of outcomes (or subsets of the sample space). E.g. in rolling a dice we can ask whether the outcome was an even number, which means asking after the event "even" = E = {2,4,6}. In simple situations with a finite number of outcomes, we assign to each outcome s (∈ S) its ''probability'' (of occurrence) p(s) (written with a small p), a number between 0 and 1. It is a quite simple function, called the probability function, with the only further property that the total of all the probabilities sum up to 1. Also for events A do we speak of their probability P(A) (written with a capital P), which is simply the total of the probabilities of the outcomes in A. For a fair dice p(s) = 1/6 for each outcome s and P("even") = P(E) = 1/6+1/6+1/6 = 1/2. The general concept of probability for non-finite sample spaces is a little more complex, although it rests on the same ideas. == Introduction == === Why have probability in a statistics textbook? === Very little in mathematics is truly self contained. Many branches of mathematics touch and interact with one another, and the fields of probability and statistics are no different. A basic understanding of probability is vital in grasping basic statistics, and probability is largely abstract without statistics to determine the "real world" probabilities. This section is not meant to give a comprehensive lecture in probability, but rather simply touch on the basics that are needed for this class, covering the basics of Bayesian Analysis for those students who are looking for something a little more interesting. This knowledge will be invaluable in attempting to understand the mathematics involved in various [[Statistics:Distributions|Distributions]] that come later. === Set notion === A set is a collection of objects. We usually use capital letters to denote sets, e.g. A is the set of females in this room. *The members of a set A are called the elements of A, e.g. Patricia is an element of A (Patricia ∈ A); Patrick is not an element of A (Patrick ∉ A). *The universal set, U, is the set of all objects under consideration, e.g., U is the set of all people in this room. *The null set or empty set, ∅, has no elements, e.g., the set of males above 2.8m tall in this room is an empty set. *The complement Ac of a set A is the set of elements in U outside A, i.e. x ∈ Ac iff x ∉ A. *Let A and B be 2 sets. A is a subset of B if each element of A is also an element of B. Write A ⊂ B, e.g. the set of females wearing metal frame glasses in this room ⊂ the set of females wearing glasses in this room ⊂ the set of females in this room. • The intersection A ∩ B of two sets A and B is the set of the common elements. I.e. x ∈ A ∩ B iff x ∈ A and x ∈ B. • The union A ∪ B of two sets A and B is the set of all elements from A or B. I.e. x ∈ A ∪ B iff x ∈ A or x ∈ B. === Venn diagrams and notation === A Venn diagram visually models defined events. Each event is expressed with a circle. Events that have outcomes in common will overlap with what is known as the intersection of the events. [[Image:Venn diagram ABC BW.png|thumb|left|A Venn diagram.]] {{-}} == Probability Axioms == == Calculating Probability == === Negation === Negation is a way of saying "not ''A''", hence saying that the complement of A has occurred. Note: The complement of an event A can be expressed as A' or Ac
For example: "What is the probability that a six-sided die will '''not''' land on a one?" (five out of six, or ''p'' = 0.833) : P[ X' ] = 1 - P[ X ] [[File:GenericcomplementofeventA.png|thumb|Left|Complement of an Event]]

Or, more colloquially, "the probability of 'not X' together with the probability of 'X' equals one or 100%."
Relative frequency describes the number of successes over the total number of outcomes. For example if a coin is flipped and out of 50 flips 29 are heads then the relative frequency is \frac{29}{50}


The Union of two events is when you want to know Event A OR Event B.
This is different from "And." "And" is the intersection, whereas "OR" is the union of the events (both events put together).

[[File:Union_example.jpg‎]]
In the above example of events you will notice that...

Event A is a STAR and a DIAMOND.

Event B is a TRIANGLE and a PENTAGON and a STAR
(A ∩ B) = (A and B) = A intersect B is only the STAR
But (A ∪ B) = (A or B) = A Union B is EVERYTHING. The TRIANGLE, PENTAGON, STAR, and DIAMOND
Notice that both event A and Event B have the STAR in common. However, when you list the Union of the events you only list the STAR one time!
Event A = STAR, DIAMOND EVENT B = TRIANGLE, PENTAGON, STAR
When you combine them together you get (STAR + DIAMOND) + (TRIANGLE + PENTAGON + STAR) BUT WAIT!!! STAR is listed two times, so one will need to SUBTRACT the extra STAR from the list.
You should notice that it is the INTERSECTION that is listed TWICE, so you have to subtract the duplicate intersection.

=== Conjunction === Formula for the Union of Events: P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)

Example:
Let P(A) = 0.3 and P(B) = 0.2 and P(A ∩ B) = 0.15. Find P(A ∪ B).
P(A ∪ B) = (0.3) + (0.2) - (0.15) = 0.35

Example:
Let P(A) = 0.3 and P(B) = 0.2 and P(A ∩ B) = 0. Find P(A ∪ B).
Note: Since the intersection of the events is the null set, then you know the events are DISJOINT or MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE.
P(A ∪ B) = (0.3) + (0.2) - (0) = 0.5
=== Disjunction === === Law of total probability === == Conditional Probability == What is the probability of one event given that another event occurs? For example, what is the probability of a mouse finding the end of the maze, given that it finds the room before the end of the maze? This is represented as: : P[A | B] or "the probability of ''A'' given ''B''." P(A | B) = \frac{P(A\cap B)}{P(B)} If ''A'' and ''B'' are '''independent''' of one another, such as with coin tosses or child births, then: : P[A | B] = P[ A ] Thus, "what is the probability that the next child a family bears will be a boy, given that the last child is a boy." This can also be stacked where the probability of ''A'' with several "givens." : P[A | B_1, B_2, B_3 ] or "the probability of ''A'' given that B1, B2, and B3 are true?" --> === Conclusion: putting it all together === {{AltBookCat}}

{{cooknav}} | [[Cookbook:Meat and poultry|Meat and poultry]]
These were considered a great delicacy by the Romans and were raised in special earthenware jars. The animals have also apparently been an important food source in Slovenia and are still eaten today. Two recipes have survived from Roman times:
* Glazed with honey and rolled in poppy seeds (Petronius) * Stuffed them with a mixture of pork mince, dormouse meat trimmings, pepper, nuts, asafoetida and nuoc mam and then roasting or boiling them (Apicius 8.9.1)
==External links== * [http://www.glirarium.org/dormouse/cult-slovenian-persic.html The Slovenian dormouse hunting tradition]
[[Category:Esoteric meat and poultry|Edible dormouse]]

{{cooknav}} | [[Cookbook:Meat and poultry|Meat and poultry]]
The old Romany (gypsy) way to cook a hedgehog is to roll it in clay and bake it in the embers of a bonfire. When ready, the clay is broken open and the spines come away still embedded in it.
[[Category:Esoteric meat and poultry]]

{{cooknav}} | [[Cookbook:Meat|Meat]]
[[Image:Two_adult_Guinea_Pigs_(Cavia_porcellus).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Guinea Pigs]]
'''Guinea pigs''' are a traditional food source in the Andes. Meals incorporating guinea pig are particularly associated with ceremonial occasions. Although the meat was for a time falling out of favour there has been a resurgence in its consumption. The most traditional Peruvian manner of cooking guinea pig involves building a stone pit and lining it with llama dung and firewood and then burying guinea pig carcasses in the coals once the fire has built up heat.
==External links==
* http://archives.thedaily.washington.edu/1997/011697/guinea011697.html * http://www.marxmail.org/archives/december98/guinea_pig.htm * http://www.cipav.org.co/lrrd/lrrd9/5/gp951.htm
[[Category:Esoteric meat and poultry|Guinea Pig]]

{{recipesummary|Fish recipes|4|1 hour|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine_of_Thailand|Thai Cuisine]]
'''Chu Chee Fish''' is whole [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] in ''kaeng chuu chee curry'' [[Cookbook:Sauces|sauce]] with lime leaves.
This very tasty distinctly [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Thailand|Thai]] fish dish is great as one of the main courses of a Thai banquet. It is also good on its own with [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]].
==Ingredients== *650[[Cookbook:Gram|g]] whole [[cookbook:bream|bream]] or similar [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|metric cup]] vegetable [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] (reserve 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] for [[Cookbook:Stir-frying|stir-frying]] curry paste) *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] of kaeng chu chee curry paste *6 dried [[Cookbook:Kaffir Lime Leaf|Kaffir lime leaves]] *1 metric cup [[Cookbook:Coconut Milk|coconut milk]] *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] (warning: perhaps the metric 20 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] one) of [[Cookbook:Fish Sauce|fish sauce]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] *1 fresh red [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili pepper]]
==Procedure== #In a [[Cookbook:Wok|wok]] or large [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frypan]], over high heat, [[Cookbook:Frying|fry]] fish using most of the vegetable oil, until golden on one side. It will take about five minutes. #Lower heat and, using tongs, gently turn fish over. #Turn up heat again and cook until golden. Using tongs again, lift fish gently onto a serving plate. #In the wok, gently [[cookbook:stir-fry|stir-fry]] the curry-paste and lime leaves in remaining tablespoon of oil. #Add coconut milk and fish sauce. [[Cookbook:Simmering|Simmer]] for about five minutes. #Add sugar and simmer for another five minutes. #Taste to see if extra coconut milk, fish sauce, or sugar is required. #Pour sauce over fish and garnish with cilantro and chopped chili peppers.
==Warnings== *Always wash your hands after handling chili peppers. Be especially careful not to touch your eyes, your kids, or pets.
[[Category:Curry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Thai recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Boiled recipes]] [[Category:Pan fried recipes]] [[Category:Main course recipes]]

revision.text: Hello there! [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome]] to Wikibooks! We've noticed that you've been making some great additions to the [[Cookbook]] and we ''really'' appreciate it. Why not [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]] and stay awhile? Wikibooks can use as many quality members as possible. If you ever need editing help visit [[Wikibooks:how to edit a page|how to edit a page]] and experiment at the [[Wikibooks:sandbox|sandbox]]. If you need pointers on how we title pages visit [[Wikibooks:Naming conventions]]. If you have any other questions about the project then check out [[Wikibooks:Help]] or add a question to the [[wikibooks:staff lounge|staff lounge]]. Hope to see you around for a long time to come! [[User:Gentgeen|Gentgeen]] 15:18, 11 Oct 2004 (UTC)

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] __NOTOC__ ==Ingredients== *2½ cups (approx 625 ml) warm water *1 packet dry (2 1/4 teaspoons) [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] *1 oz (30 g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] or [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *2 lb (1 kg) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1 pinch [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
==Procedure== #Put half of the water into a container, add yeast and either sugar or honey. #Take another container and put in 2 pounds(1 kg) of flour. Form a crater in the middle into which you can pour the water with the yeast. Add a pinch of salt. Knead it and keep adding water until the dough has a good thick consistency. #Place the dough on a surface and let it stand for about 1 hour. Knead again to let the air out and knead it into the shape of a bread. Let it stand for another 45 minutes. #[[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] in an oven at 375°F (200 °C) for 50-60 minutes or until the internal temperature is about 200°F(95 °C). #Now you have a nice, tasty loaf of bread.
==Tips== If your bread seems crumbly or not sufficiently soft and bouncy, try using high gluten flour. You can get special bread making flour which is higher in gluten than normal flour.
==External links== *[http://www.homebaking.mobi/bread/milk-bread.htm Enriched White Bread Recipe]
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]] [[Category:Baking recipes]]

{{recipe}}
'''Fried chicken''' has a dual origin in the rural American South. The Scots had a tradition of shallow cooking chicken in fat (not quite pan frying), unlike their English counterparts who baked or boiled chicken. Later, as African slaves were introduced to households as cooks, seasonings and spices were added that are absent in traditional Scottish cuisine, improving the flavor and they brought the concept of deep fat frying. Since slaves were often allowed to keep only chickens, frying chicken as a special occasion spread through the African American community. After slavery, poor rural southern blacks continued the tradition since chickens were often the only animals they could afford to raise. Since fried chicken could keep for several days, it travelled well, and also gained favor during segregation when blacks normally could not find places to eat and had to carry their own food. Southern whites also continued the tradition of frying chicken. Therefore, fried chicken continued to dominate as "Sunday dinner" or on other special occasions.
==Ingredients==
*1 fryer [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]], cut up (see notes below) *1 quart [[Cookbook:milk|buttermilk]] *½ cup [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *[[Cookbook:Spice rub|Spice rub]] (paprika is highly recommended. See below for how to prepare) *[[Cookbook:Flour|Flour]] *A quantity of [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] suitable for the desired cooking method (see notes below)
==Procedure== ===Preparing the spice rub=== #Put a large amount of the spice in a bowl. #Add slightly less of some other seasonings, such as [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]]. Mix it up. You now have a spice rub.
===Brining the chicken=== #Pour the buttermilk into a bowl and dissolve ½ cup of salt in the buttermilk. #Piece by piece, roll the chicken around in the spice rub. #Submerge each chicken piece in the buttermilk. #Cover the bowl of buttermilk and chicken and refrigerate. (You can get by with as few as two hours if you are in a hurry, but the flavor will suffer. You can also park it overnight, but you should reduce the salt to ⅓ of a cup) #Shortly before you want to cook the chicken, remove it from the buttermilk and drain. Roll it around in flour so that it is well covered in flour. Shake off the excess flour.
===Cooking the chicken, deep frying method=== #The safest cooking method is [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep frying]]. Immerse chicken in 360°F oil. Cooking times are: #*Breasts: 10 minutes #*Drumsticks: 12 minutes #*Thighs: 13-14 minutes #*Wings: 10 minutes (though wings are often better suited to other applications) #Drain the chicken on a wire rack (place it over a sheet pan to catch the oil).
===Variation 1, pan frying method=== #The most traditional cooking method is [[Cookbook:Pan Frying|pan frying]] in a [[Cookbook:Cast iron|cast iron skillet]]. Care must be taken to avoid spilling and splattering. #Heat enough oil (or shortening) to come 3-4mm up the side of the pan to 325°F. #Carefully place chicken in pan, skin side down, and cook until brown, 10-12 minutes. Turn over and cook other side. #Doing this will require some careful placement in the pan so as to cook the slow-cooking meat (such as thighs) more intensely than the fast-cooking meat (such as wings and breasts). #Drain the chicken on a wire rack (place it over a sheet pan to catch the oil).
===Variation 2, pressure frying method=== #[[Cookbook:Pressure frying|Pressure frying]] gives excellent results, but special equipment is needed. A typical pressure cooker is not suitable for cooking with large quantities of oil; a pressure fryer must be used. Follow the manufacturer's instructions carefully. #Put the chicken pieces into hot oil (larger pieces first) and fry about 3 minutes until very light brown. Then put on the lid and lock it. #Cook at a pressure of 5-6 pounds for about 7 minutes. #Drain the chicken on a wire rack (place it over a sheet pan to catch the oil).
==Notes, Tips, and Variations== *The key to this recipe is the buttermilk brine, which seasons the chicken with a salty tanginess inside. Combined with a suitably zingy spice rub, this works out beautifully. *This recipe is death to oil, so it's one you might want to save until you're thinking about changing your fryer oil anyway. *As with all respectable fried chicken recipes, this recipe may be even better 24 hours after you cook it, when the chicken has been refrigerated. *If you can get a pre-cut chicken, this is ultimately easier. Alternatively, if you have a real preference for drumsticks, thighs, breasts, or some other part, feel free to buy just those. The quantities in the ingredient list, however, reflect two breasts, two thighs, and two drumsticks. (Don't waste the other parts on fried chicken; save them for chicken soup! But if you like fried chicken wings, increase the quantities a bit.) *If you are kosher, lactose intolerant, not fond of buttermilk, or feeling experimental, feel free to play around with other possible brines here. If you use a less [[Wikipedia:viscous|viscous]] liquid than buttermilk, however, you may need to use an egg wash to make sure that the flour sticks to the chicken in sufficient quantity. *Wings can also be saved, along with other leftover bits of carcass, to make [[Cookbook:Chicken Soup|chicken soup]]. *Personal preference chooses which spice to use as a base. A [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]] based rub works very well for this recipe, but others will work just fine. [[Cookbook:Cumin|Cumin]] or [[Cookbook:Curry Powder|curry powder]] would also both be good choices. You can use [[Cookbook:Rosemary|Rosemary Powder]] and [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|Green Bell Pepper Powder]] in order to give a more mediterranean taste to fried chicken.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Deep fried recipes]] [[Category:Main course recipes]] [[Category:Southern U.S. recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: moved [[Internet Technologies/History and Evolution]] to [[Internet Technologies/History and evolution]]: move for consistency with other pages in this book
revision.text:
The Internet began life as a research project sponsored by ARPA. Previously US defense computers were connected to each other in a one way fashion such that each computer was connected to the others in series. In case of one computer being destroyed all others would lose communication. To avoid this the government decided to connect the computers in a web with each computer connected to all others. The motivation was to connect the few then existing proprietary computer networks to one interconnected network. The first version of the Internet was called ARPANET and was implemented in 1969. It then consisted of 4 Nodes in UCLA, UC Santa Barbara, Stanford Research Lab, and the University of Utah. It was to be the predecessor of what is today called the Internet.
[[Category:Internet Technologies]]

Try changing your external links to put inside double square brackets before and after. Thus, in your formatting it would look like: ([[http://www.url.com/]]) (edit this page to view) == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Wjgilmore. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Wjgilmore~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
23:54, 17 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: i.e → i.e. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{General Mechanics}}
We've seen that an Hamiltonian of the form
:<math>H=\frac{\mathbf{p}\cdot\mathbf{p}}{2m}+V(\mathbf{r})</math>
describes motion under a conservative force, but this is not the most general possible Hamiltonian.
Many waves are described by another simple form, in the geometrical optics limit,
:<math>H=f(|\mathbf{p}|)</math>
What happens if we consider other forms for the Hamiltonian?
Suppose we have
:<math>H=\frac{\mathbf{p}\cdot\mathbf{p}}{2m} + \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})</math>
The dot product term is the simplest scalar we can add to the kinetic energy that's dependent on momentum. We'll see that it acts like a potential energy.
Using Hamilton's equations we can immediately write down equations of motion.
:<math>\begin{matrix} \dot{x}_i & = & \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_i} & = & \frac{p_i}{m} + A_i \\ \dot{p}_i & = & -\frac{\partial H}{\partial x_i} & = & -p_j \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} \end{matrix}</math>
Note that we are using the [[../Index Notation|summation convention]] here.
Now that we've got the equations of motion, we need to work out what they mean.
The first thing we notice is that the momentum is no longer ''m'''v'''''. There is an additional contribution from the potential field '''A'''. We can think of this as a form of ''potential momentum'', analogous to potential energy.
The force on the particle is
:<math>F_i = m \ddot{x}_i = \dot{p}_i + m\frac{d}{dt}A_i(\mathbf{r})</math>
Using the chain rule, and substituting for ''dp''/''dt'' with the second equation of motion, we get
:<math>F_i = -p_j \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} + m\dot{x}_j \frac{\partial A_i}{\partial x_j} </math>
Using the first equation, this becomes
:<math>F_i = m \dot{x}_j \left( \frac{\partial A_i}{\partial x_j} -\frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} \right) + m A_j \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} </math>
The term in brackets is recognizable as being the type of thing we see in cross products. With a little manipulation, using the Kronecker delta and alternating symbol, we can write
:<math>\begin{matrix} F_i & = & \dot{x}_j \left( \delta_{il}\delta_{jk}-\delta_{ik}\delta_{jl} \right) \frac{\partial A_l}{\partial x_k} & + & m A_j \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} \\ & = & \dot{x}_j \epsilon_{nij} \epsilon_{nlk} \frac{\partial A_l}{\partial x_k} & + & m A_j \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} \\ & = & -\epsilon_{ijn} \dot{x}_j \left( \nabla \times \mathbf{A} \right)_n & + & m A_j \frac{\partial A_j}{\partial x_i} \\ & = & -\epsilon_{ijn} \dot{x}_j \left( \nabla \times \mathbf{A} \right)_n & + & \frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_i} A_j A_j \end{matrix}</math>
so, writing the last line as a vector equation,
:<math> \mathbf{F} = -m \mathbf{v} \times (\nabla \times \mathbf{A}) + \frac{1}{2} m \nabla A^2 </math>
The force from this potential has a component perpendicular to its curl and to the velocity, and another component which is the gradient of a scalar.
If we add a carefully chosen potential energy to the Hamiltonian we can cancel out this second term.
:<math>H=\frac{p^2}{2m} + \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r}) + \frac{1}{2} m A^2 \qquad \mathbf{F}= -m \mathbf{v} \times \left (\nabla \times \mathbf{A} \right) </math>
This Hamiltonian can be simplified to
:<math>H = \frac{1}{2m} \left( \mathbf{p}+ m\mathbf{A} \right)^2 </math>
where the term in bracket is ''m'''v''''', written as a function of momentum.
This simple modification to the Hamiltonian gives us a force perpendicular to velocity, like magnetism. Because the force and velocity are perpendicular, the work done by the force is always zero.
''We can use potential fields to describe velocity dependent forces, provided that they do no work.''
The coefficient of '''A''' in these expression is arbitrary. Changing it amount merely to measuring '''A''' in different units so we can equally well write
:<math>H = \frac{1}{2m} \left( \mathbf{p}+ \alpha\mathbf{A} \right)^2 \qquad \mathbf{F}= -\alpha \mathbf{v} \times \left (\nabla \times \mathbf{A} \right) </math>
Having α=''m'' means '''A''' is measured in units of velocity, which may sometimes be convenient, but we can use any other constant value of α that suits our purpose. When we come to study relativity, we'll use α=-1.
Notice that the force depends only on the curl of '''A''', not on '''A''' itself. This means we can add any function with zero curl to '''A''' without changing anything, just as we can add a constant to the potential energy.
Furthermore, it is a standard result of vector calculus that any vector field is the sum of two components, one with zero curl, the other with zero divergence. Since the zero curl component does not affect the total force, we can require it to be zero; i.e. we can require '''A''' to have zero divergence.
:<math> \nabla \cdot \mathbf{A}= 0 </math>
This is called a ''gauge'' condition. For the moment, it can be considered to define especially natural values for the integration constants.

revision.text:
I am studying Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, Computer Science, and Physics in college, so these are my primary academic interests at this time.
<s>You can also check out my [http://hdub.servebeer.com website] to learn more.<s>
I am also a long time contributer to [http://en.wikipedia.org Wikipedia]; see my [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:CyborgTosser user page] there.

As I understand it, the "60% chance of rain" means that rain is expected to fall on about 60% of the area. Perhaps there is a better everyday example. [[User:CyborgTosser|CyborgTosser]] 08:12, 12 Oct 2004 (UTC)
Eibwen, you are mistaken about odds. Please see the Wikipedia article on [[w:Odds|odds]]. As it says both here in the text, and there, odds is the ratio of the probability an event will happen to the probability it will not happen. Mathematically, odds = p/(1-p). The probability a coin will land heads is 50%. The probability it will not land heads is 50%. Therefore, the odds it will land heads is 50%/50% = 1:1, not 1:2. [[User:CyborgTosser|CyborgTosser]] 08:18, 12 Oct 2004 (UTC)
The approach in the material I have added, by the way, is loosely based on ''Probability and Random Processes with Applications to Signal Processing'' by Henry Stark and John W. Woods. [[User:CyborgTosser|CyborgTosser]] 10:47, 12 Oct 2004 (UTC)
==Abstract Algebra== It would seem that if somebody had a passable grasp of abstract algebra (other than what you might learn about Fields in freshman year courses) then you'd think that they'd probably have been introduced to probablility to some extent. Wouldn't it be better to omit the abstract algebra if at all possible?

{{cookdp}} | [[Cookbook:Baking|Baking]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
'''Pastry''' is made from a mixture of (at minimum) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]], fat and water, used to encase or cover food in the form of [[Cookbook:Pie|pies]], [[Cookbook:Tart|tarts]] etc.
Pastry is generally dry, delicate, and flaky. The delicacy and flakiness of a pastry is determined by how much the dough is mixed, how thin the dough is, how much fat is involved, and the melting properties of the fat. A [[Cookbook:Pie_Crust|pie crust]], for instance, is delicate due to the relatively low amount of mixing (and hence, low gluten production), and is flaky due to the high fat to flour ratio. A [[Cookbook:Croissant|croissant]] dough, unlike a pie crust, will endure a high amount of mixing (thus more gluten) but the dough is rolled into very thin layers between a large amount of fat.
One of the main goals of pastry dough preparation is to avoid combining the fat and the other ingredients. The fat should be distributed in the other ingredients while remaining unique from them; in a pie crust this is achieved by using a [[Cookbook:Pastry Blender|pastry blender]] to cut the fat into small chunks, which "float" in the rest of the ingredients, while in a croissant this is achieved by mixing the dough separately, folding the dough over the fat, then rolling and folding the dough over itself a number of times to produce distinct layers of dough and fat.
=Pastry Dough Recipes= *[[Cookbook:Pie Crust|Pie Crust]] *[[Cookbook:Paste_for_tarts|Paste for Tarts]]
